text: String theory proposes that fundamental particles are actually vibrating strings, offering a potential framework for unifying all forces.
The theory of general relativity describes gravity not as a force, but as the curvature of spacetime caused by mass and energy.
Quantum mechanics governs the behavior of matter at the atomic and subatomic levels, characterized by probabilities and uncertainties.
Evolution by natural selection explains how species change over time, with advantageous traits becoming more common.
The Big Bang theory suggests the universe originated from an extremely hot, dense state and has been expanding ever since.
Plate tectonics explains the Earth's geological features, such as mountains and volcanoes, through the movement of lithospheric plates.
Germ theory of disease revolutionized medicine by demonstrating that many diseases are caused by microorganisms.
Cell theory states that all living organisms are composed of cells, the fundamental units of life.
The standard model of particle physics classifies fundamental particles and forces, but doesn't include gravity.
Chaos theory explores complex systems where small initial changes can lead to drastically different outcomes.
The Doppler effect explains the change in frequency of a wave (like light or sound) due to the motion of the source or observer.
Conservation of energy states that the total energy of an isolated system remains constant over time.
Special relativity introduced the concept of spacetime and the constancy of the speed of light.
Mendelian genetics explains inheritance through discrete units called genes, which are passed from parents to offspring.
The law of thermodynamics describes energy transfer and transformation in physical systems, including the concept of entropy.
Hubble's law states that the recessional velocity of galaxies is proportional to their distance from Earth, supporting the Big Bang.
Avogadro's law relates the volume of a gas to the number of molecules it contains at a constant temperature and pressure.
Newton's law of universal gravitation states that every particle attracts every other particle with a force proportional to their masses.
The theory of abiogenesis proposes how life arose from non-living matter through natural processes.
Ekman transport, arising from Coriolis, means water moves 90Â° from the wind direction; crucial to understanding ocean circulation.
Einstein's theory of relativity revolutionized physics, linking space and time in a way previously unimaginable.
The Big Bang theory posits that the universe originated from an extremely hot, dense state.
Evolution by natural selection, as proposed by Darwin, explains the diversity of life on Earth.
Quantum mechanics governs the behavior of matter and energy at the atomic and subatomic levels.
Plate tectonics explains the movement of Earth's lithosphere and the formation of geological features.
String theory attempts to unify all fundamental forces of nature into a single, elegant framework.
Germ theory demonstrates that many diseases are caused by microorganisms.
General relativity predicts the existence of black holes, regions of spacetime with immense gravity.
The Standard Model of particle physics describes the fundamental particles and their interactions.
Mendelian genetics explains how traits are inherited from parents to offspring.
The theory of abiogenesis suggests that life arose from non-living matter through natural processes.
Chaos theory studies complex systems whose behavior is highly sensitive to initial conditions.
Game theory analyzes strategic interactions between rational decision-makers.
Information theory quantifies the amount of information contained in a message.
The theory of cognitive dissonance explores the mental discomfort caused by conflicting beliefs.
The holographic principle suggests that the description of a volume of space can be thought of as encoded on a boundary to the region.
Thermodynamics deals with heat, work, and energy, and the laws governing their transfer.
Cell theory states that all living organisms are composed of cells.
The theory of electromagnetism describes the interaction of electric and magnetic fields.
Network theory examines complex systems by analyzing relationships and interactions between components.
General relativity, while beautiful, faces challenges integrating with quantum mechanics. A unified theory remains elusive.
Evolutionary theory highlights adaptation, yet random mutations drive significant change.
String theory proposes extra dimensions, though experimental verification remains distant.
The Standard Model elegantly describes fundamental particles and forces, excluding gravity.
Plate tectonics explains continental drift, driven by convection in Earth's mantle.
Big Bang theory describes the universe's origin, supported by cosmic microwave background radiation.
Cell theory states that all living organisms are composed of cells. Simple, but foundational.
Chaos theory demonstrates sensitivity to initial conditions, impacting weather prediction.
Information theory quantifies data communication and storage. It's more than just bytes.
Game theory analyzes strategic interactions, useful in economics and political science.
Cognitive dissonance theory explores discomfort arising from conflicting beliefs and attitudes.
Germ theory posits that microorganisms cause diseases, revolutionizing medicine.
Climate models simulate Earth's climate, but uncertainties regarding cloud behavior persist.
The Nash equilibrium offers a profile where no player has any motivation to change strategy.
Quantum entanglement, a bizarre quantum phenomenon, exhibits correlated behavior across vast distances.
The Gaia hypothesis considers Earth a self-regulating system. Highly debated among scientists.
The Pauli Exclusion Principle dictates that no two identical fermions may occupy the same quantum state simultaneously.
Hubble's Law, a cornerstone of cosmology, describes the expansion rate of the universe based on redshift.
Dark matter and dark energy comprise most of the universe's mass-energy density, still shrouded in mystery.
Mendelian genetics explains inheritance patterns, but modifications exist due to epigenetic factors.
Einstein's theory of relativity revolutionized our understanding of gravity, proposing that it's the curvature of spacetime caused by mass and energy.
Quantum mechanics suggests that energy, momentum, and other properties of a system are quantized, meaning they can only take on discrete values.
The Big Bang theory posits that the universe originated from an extremely hot and dense state and has been expanding ever since.
Darwin's theory of evolution explains the diversity of life on Earth through natural selection and genetic variation.
Plate tectonics describes how the Earth's lithosphere is divided into plates that move and interact, causing earthquakes and volcanoes.
Germ theory states that many diseases are caused by microorganisms, such as bacteria and viruses.
String theory attempts to unify all fundamental forces and particles into a single framework by positing that fundamental constituents are one-dimensional strings.
The theory of general relativity predicted the existence of gravitational waves, ripples in spacetime caused by accelerating masses, later confirmed experimentally.
Cell theory states that all living organisms are composed of cells and that all cells arise from pre-existing cells.
Chaos theory explores systems that are highly sensitive to initial conditions, making long-term prediction difficult or impossible.
The standard model of particle physics describes the fundamental particles and forces of nature, except for gravity.
Information theory provides a mathematical framework for quantifying, storing, and communicating information.
Game theory analyzes strategic interactions between rational decision-makers.
Cognitive dissonance theory suggests that people strive for consistency between their beliefs and behaviors, and experience discomfort when they are inconsistent.
The central dogma of molecular biology outlines the flow of genetic information from DNA to RNA to protein.
Systems theory examines the interrelationships between parts of a whole and provides the basic principles to guide organizational decision-making.
Maslow's hierarchy of needs is a motivational theory comprising a five-tier model of human needs, often depicted as hierarchical levels within a pyramid.
The tragedy of the commons is an economic problem where individuals with access to a shared resource act independently in their own self-interest and ultimately deplete the resource.
Agency theory studies the relationship between principals and agents, addressing problems of asymmetric information and differing goals.
Black hole thermodynamics relates the geometry and properties of black holes to thermodynamic quantities like entropy and temperature.
General Relativity beautifully describes gravity as the curvature of spacetime, impacting how we perceive the universe.
Quantum mechanics, though bizarre, has revolutionized technology, from lasers to semiconductors. Its predictions are undeniably precise.
Evolution by natural selection explains the diversity of life, a process observable even today in microbial populations.
The Big Bang theory provides a compelling narrative for the universe's origin and expansion, supported by cosmic background radiation.
Plate tectonics revolutionized geology, explaining earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain formation with continental drift.
Germ theory of disease saved countless lives by recognizing that microbes cause infection. A cornerstone of modern medicine.
String theory, a controversial model, aims to unify all fundamental forces, though experimental verification remains elusive.
The Standard Model of particle physics catalogs known elementary particles, but leaves gaps concerning dark matter and gravity.
The Theory of Computation formalizes limits to what computers can compute. The Halting problem stands as a fundamental barrier.
Information theory quantifies information, impacting areas from coding to communication. Shannon's work defines boundaries.
Chaos theory illustrates how small changes can yield unpredictable effects in complex systems like weather.
Game theory models strategic interactions, shaping fields like economics and political science with rational-actor modeling.
The cell theory is a founding tenant of biology stating that all life is composed of cells and cells come from other cells.
Einstein's theory of special relativity redefined our notions of space and time, and led to e=mc^2.
Chaos theory demonstrates that complex systems like the weather have underlying patterns and inherent unpredictability.
Network theory illustrates the way that items are interconnected to create emergent behavior such as robustness and inefficiency.
Cognitive dissonance theory says that conflicting values may be changed when held simultaneously to cause comfort and ease.
Systems theory attempts to define a clear hierarchy of interrelated entities that impact each other's states.
Fluid dynamics attempts to predict the movement of liquids and gases, like in airplane wing construction.
Lamarck's theory of evolution, an earlier alternative, suggested inheritance of acquired characteristics, now largely discredited.
